docs.lead_paragraph: If you liked Prozac, you'll love what's coming next. Neuroscientists are proclaiming that the ''Decade of the Brain,'' an intensive program of basic research started by the National Institute of Mental Health, is about to pay off in a new generation of much-improved psychiatric drugs.

headline.main: Coming Soon to a Prozac Nation

docs.abstract: Neuroscientists have announced that intensive program of basic research started by National Institute of Mental Health is about to pay off in new generation of much-improved psychiatric drugs; photo (S)
docs.snippet: If you liked Prozac, you'll love what's coming next. Neuroscientists are proclaiming that the ''Decade of the Brain,'' an intensive program of basic research started by the National Institute of Mental Health, is about to pay off in a new generation...

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER AT&T began offering acupuncture to its management employees as an option in one of its health insurance plans in January, the company said ''less than a handful'' of workers sought treatment. Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest H.M.O., had more success, saying it had strong demand at its clinics in California that offered acupuncture and other alternative medical services. Alternative medicine, long on the fringes of medical care, is slowly being offered by more health plans. While most states require health insurers to cover chiropractic care, some states have gone further, requiring many insurers to cover treatments like acupuncture and naturopathy.

headline.main: Now in the H.M.O.: Yoga Teachers and Naturopaths

docs.abstract: Alternative medicine, long on the fringes of medical care, is slowly being offered by more health plans; for example, Oxford Health Plans, Norwalk, Conn, recently took alternative medicine beyond state mandates, announcing that it would become first large medical insurer to have network of alternative-care providers; although medical community has increasingly incorporated some forms of alternative medicine in traditional treatments, doctors caution that many forms of alternative care are still being tested and question whether Oxford's action is too much too soon; photo (M)
